div.p: VPRS 5834/P0/1, inward correspondence p. 21, VA 1411 Industrial and Technological Museum, Public Record Office, Victoria.

Allow me to ask you, dear Mr Bright, whether you will be so good to ask your cotrustees of the public Library and Industrial museum, to afford me some aid in continuing to work in my laboratory for preparing technologic articles from vegetable substances for the new Museum. The resources of my department became some months ago reduced at a rate of £2000 pro anno, and thus it is utterly an impossibility to me to maintain my phytologic researches quite unaided by some help. It is true, that you and your colleagues kindly promised to pay for the printing of labels (within a limited sum), also for glass-vessels
See M to A. Tulk, 17 June 1870 (in this edition as 70-06-17a). See also M to M. Clarke, 27 July 1870 (in this edition as 70-07-27a). and for the plaining
planing? and publishing of the woodspecimens and similar work. But this concession does not meet the expenditure in preparing
the articles , but merely to set them up instructively and elegantly. The expenditure in my department for laboratory work during 1870 has hitherto been already over £100, and to continue the works commenced til the end of the year will involve an other £100 expenses, notwithstanding that gradually many apparatus & other facilities are available. This expenditure I am utterly unable to meet either from my private or public resources, and would therefore ask the Commissioners or Trustees of the Museum to supplement the fund necessary for the work til the end of the year by £50 (fifty pounds). Then the work can proceed unchecked, and a detail account of the expenditure will be rendered. I may yet remark, that it is only in my own establishment here, where the raw material is fresh at hand and where other facilities exist, that the phytochemic articles can be readily prepared.

It is scarcely necessary to remark, that the whole £50 would be expended for the sole and exclusive benefit the phytologic section of the Museum.
MS annotation: 'Regret that there is no money on the Estimates to enable [us] to supplement the expenses of your research [illegible initials]'.
